CatDescriptText: David Crozier, student, Squirrel Hill and William O'Donnell, student, Castle Shannon, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 4, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think the names of juveniles who commit felonies, as distinguished from misdemeanors, should be published in the newspapers?"  David Crozier's answer reads: "I think that what should be done is a study of the effect that the publishing of names has on juveniles.  This study should be conducted by a competent psychologist.  If it reveals that it would help the youngsters by keeping his name from the paper, well, than I'm all in favor of it."  William O'Donnell's answer reads: "I don't think they should be published, because a lot of kids commit crimes just to get their names in the paper."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of David Crozier wearing eyeglasses, moustache, light colored jacket with toggle buttons, holding bag under right arm, standing in front of store window with Candy sign; Portrait of William O'Donnell wearing plaid shirt and jacket with square buttons, standing in front of store window with Candy sign
